subject: Proposal for chassis 'obmc-chassis-blackout@.target'
commitMessage:
Proposal for chassis 'obmc-chassis-blackout@.target'

Some OpenBMC systems have services they need run after a system blackout
occurs. This design change proposes a new target to coordinate these
services.

Signed-off-by: Corey Hardesty <corey.hardesty@icloud.com>
Change-Id: I7798b758a539bfae408ddf1d8422b144fcaf7a34

So definitely want a brief high level statement on why this commit is being done. "Some OpenBMC systems have services they need run after a system blackout occurs. This design change proposes a new target to coordinate these services".
Thanks for getting this rolling Corey!
Lets add a new paragraph here that describes the new problem. That is, some OpenBMC servers require specific services, like clearing all lit LED's, after a blackout occurs.
General: Make sure you're following the 80 char limit. I see multiple lines that exceed 80 char and I also see some blank spaces at the end of lines.
I'm not sure where this one comes from? Is it just a sub-bullet of the above requirement? If so, probably not needed here.

Lets make this more generic. "Provide a generic target, obmc-chassis-blackout@.target, which will be called when a blackout is detected.". What goes in that target will most likely be system specific (IBM will put the service to turn off any active LED's)
Best to just keep all the requirements in order. I don't think this line is needed.
Seems redundant with line 101, I think you can remove
"allow system owners to call services in this condition." There is no chassis state change per-se here so lets not imply it.
"The target will allow system owners to add their own specific services to this target"
I think you can strike this as well. Power restore is documented well elsewhere in this doc. We just want to focus on the new target in this section.
This doesn't make a ton of sense. I think you may have systemd target and services a little confused. But either way, I think you can strike this whole paragraph as the other text above covers this.
Is this on the right track? Targets are used as units to setup and configure a state of the machine while services are used to launch processes.
I think you can scratch this paragraph. The first one captures the gist of the issue and people can read the design doc for more background.

This one is not reading as cleanly as I'd prefer. Try and keep it more sweet and simple for problem description. "During blackout scenarios, system owners may have a set of services they need run once the power is restored. For example, IBM requires all LED's be toggled to off in a blackout. Need to provide a mechanism for system owners to run services in this scenario"
not a new bullet, also I'd say just scrap the last part of this bullet and just keep it to "Adhere to the current power restore policy". The details of that policy are captured elsewhere.
Empty space at end of line
Make this consistent with other mention of this target. Probably just obmc-chassis-blackout@.target.
"phosphor-chassis-state-manager will ensure this new target is called on power restoration after a blackout"
So for this part, you should have the full target name, so searches later can find this easily - "obmc-chassis-blackout@.target"
This part of the sentence is not very clear to me either. I think you can strike it as well.
I think you can strike this as well. The next paragraph is short and sweet on describing the problem you're looking to solve.
Add a new line above this to separate out the requirement blocks.
obmc-chassis-blackout@.target. Also, instead of "" around strings like this, use ``. It formats better in markdown.
ping. Anything else you'd like to see here Patrick? We're getting close to merging the code changes.
I think I'm mostly ok with this.  Maybe some minor discussion to be had before we merge it.

I know what you mean by this, but many systems don't actually get "AC power" (for example, nothing in an OCP rack has AC delivered to the system).  We have similar confusion in other parts of the document so as long as we are consistent this is probably the right way to describe this for now.
Ahh, good point. We'll need a scrubbing some day. Something like "system power" maybe.
Is there any hardware support we are leveraging to identify this case?  Can we identify them?  It isn't obvious to me how you would identify this.

That would be nice, but currently it's just a the chassis-state-manager remembering the last power state and comparing it against the pgood pin after a BMC reboot. Corey please add this detail as a blurb here.
Is this really a 'must' or a 'may' (or a 'should')?
"may" is fine, definitely not a requirement to install this target say if you are using x86-power-control.
